items.message: Flooding is possible through Wednesday and Thursday as river levels continue to rise due to heavy rainfall overnight and continuing lighter rainfall today. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Further rain is forecast through to Saturday and levels are expected to continue rising. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will issue further alerts and warnings if required. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and consider activating any flood protection products you may have. This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 13/11/2025 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Evenlode from Moreton in Marsh to Cassington and also the River Glyme at Wootton and Woodstock
items.message:
There is no longer a threat of flooding, though standing water and debris may still remain. 
Further rainfall is forecast but no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. Stay away from floodwater - it contains hidden dangers such as open manhole covers, sewage and chemicals.

items.description: River Stour and Smestow Brook in the Black Country and South Staffordshire
items.message:
High river levels today may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 12 November 2025 . 
Locations most affected will be low lying land and roads near rivers. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water . 
This message will be updated by 11:00AM on 13 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

The flood forecast has changed significantly. As a result, there is no longer a risk of flooding in the area. 
Weather conditions are expected to improve and no further flooding is expected.   
We will continue to monitor the situation and will issue further alerts or warnings if necessary.   
Never drive through flood water,  just 30cm of fast flowing water is enough to move your car. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger.

Forecast rising river levels overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible on 11 and 12 November 2025. 
Locations most affected will be low lying land, roads and paths near rivers; including roads at Ashford Mill, Isle Brewers, Fivehead, the Norton sub Hambdon to Stratton road, the A356 and the B3165 at Chiselborough and the B3168 at Ilford Bridges.
Further flooding is possible tomorrow as river levels continue to rise due to additional rain. 
 
We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and will update this message as the situation changes. 
Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and consider activating any flood protection products you may have. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.eaAreaName: Devon, Cornwall and the Isles of Scilly

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Coly, River Yarty, Umborne Brook

items.message:
Forecast rising river levels overnight may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the early hours of 12 November 2025 . 
Heavy and persistent rainfall is expected on Tuesday evening and overnight. River levels are expected to rise in response to the rainfall.

Forecast levels may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 12:30AM on Wednesday. The main areas of concern are Seaton, Colyton, Axminster and Axmouth.

We expect the river to remain high into Wednesday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Teme, River Onny, River Corve

items.message: Forecast rising river levels today may lead to flooding.  Flooding is possible from 12 November 2025.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent the River Teme, River Onny and River Corve and their tributaries. Locations that may be affected include Bishops Castle, Church Stretton, Knighton and Ludlow.  Predicted peaks:- Leintwardine 0.9m to 1.1m 13/11 PM and 1.9m to 2.3m 15/11 AM, Onibury 1.3m to 1.6m 12/11 PM and 2.8m to 3.3m 15/11 AM, Corve 1.5m to 2.0m 13/11 AM and 2.5m to 3.0m 15/11 AM. We are closely monitoring the situation.  Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.  This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
Forecast rising river levels this evening may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from the evening of 11 November 2025 . 
Heavy and persistent rainfall is expected from Tuesday evening and overnight. River levels are expected to rise in response to the rainfall. 

Forecast levels may cause flooding to low lying land and roads close to the river from around 09:00PM on Tuesday. The main areas of concern are Newton Abbot, Kingsteignton, Teignmouth, Shaldon, Bovey Tracey, Kingskerswell, Dawlish and Dawlish Warren.

We expect rivers to remain high into Wednesday. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded . 
This message will be updated by 2:00PM on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

High river levels today may lead to flooding.  Flooding is possible from the morning of 12 November 2025.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Roads between Maesbrook, Melverley and Pentre start to flood.  Predicted peaks:-  Llanymynech 4.0m 12/11 AM, Cae Howel 3.4m to 3.6m on 12/11 PM.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded and monitor local water levels and weather conditions.  This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

Forecast rising river levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 12 November 2025. 
Flooding may affect low lying land and roads along the River Wye from Hay on Wye to Ross on Wye. Other locations affected may include the A438 between Letton & Willersey, Byford, Bredwardine & Hereford. Road closures & diversions on the A438 may be in force. Predicted peaks:- Hay on Wye 1.7m to 2.1m on 13/11 AM, second peak Saturday, Bredwardine 3.0m to 3.5m on 13/11 AM, second peak Saturday, Belmont 3.3m to 3.6m on 13/11 AM, second peak Saturday, Old Wye Bridge 2.9m to 3.2m on 13/11 AM, second peak Saturday, Mordiford 3.3m to 3.7m on 13/11 AM, second peak Saturday, Ross on Wye 3.4m to 3.7m on 13/11PM, second peak Saturday or Sunday.
Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. 
This message will be updated by 7:00PM on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.

items.message:
River and lake levels are high following heavy rainfall on Tuesday 11th November 2025.  Further rain is expected on Wednesday evening, which will cause the level of Derwentwater to remain high.

We continue to monitor the situation.

Do not walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10:00AM on 13th November 2025.

items.description: River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell
items.message:
High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 12 November 2025.

Areas most at risk are those around the River Great Ouse from Thornborough to Newport Pagnell, including Dogsmouth Brook. Heavy rainfall is forecast on Friday which will cause levels to rise.

We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. Monitor local water levels and weather conditions. 

This message will be updated by 17:00 on 12 November 2025 or as the situation changes.
